net.opentsdb.core

Class Tags

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.opentsdb.core.Tags

  • public final class Tags
extends Object
    Helper functions to deal with tags.

    • Method Detail

      • splitString

        public static String[] splitString(String s,
                   char c)
        Optimized version of String#split that doesn't use regexps. This function works in O(5n) where n is the length of the string to split.
        Parameters:
        s - The string to split.
        c - The separator to use to split the string.
        Returns:
        A non-null, non-empty array.

      • parse

        public static void parse(HashMap<String,String> tags,
         String tag)
        Parses a tag into a HashMap.
        Parameters:
        tags - The HashMap into which to store the tag.
        tag - A String of the form "tag=value".
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the tag is malformed.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the tag was already in tags with a different value.

      • parse

        public static void parse(List<Pair<String,String>> tags,
         String tag)
        Parses a tag into a list of key/value pairs, allowing nulls for either value.
        Parameters:
        tags - The list into which the parsed tag should be stored
        tag - A string of the form "tag=value" or "=value" or "tag="
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the tag is malformed.
        Since:
        2.1

      • parseWithMetric

        public static String parseWithMetric(String metric,
                     HashMap<String,String> tags)
        Parses the metric and tags out of the given string.
        Parameters:
        metric - A string of the form "metric" or "metric{tag=value,...}".
        tags - The map to populate with the tags parsed out of the first argument.
        Returns:
        The name of the metric.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the metric is malformed.

      • parseWithMetric

        public static String parseWithMetric(String metric,
                     List<Pair<String,String>> tags)
        Parses an optional metric and tags out of the given string, any of which may be null. Requires at least one metric, tagk or tagv.
        Parameters:
        metric - A string of the form "metric" or "metric{tag=value,...}" or even "{tag=value,...}" where the metric may be missing.
        tags - The list to populate with parsed tag pairs
        Returns:
        The name of the metric if it exists, null otherwise
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the metric is malformed.
        Since:
        2.1

      • parseLong

        public static long parseLong(CharSequence s)
        Parses an integer value as a long from the given character sequence.

        This is equivalent to Long.parseLong(String) except it's up to 100% faster on String and always works in O(1) space even with StringBuilder buffers (where it's 2x to 5x faster).

        Parameters:
        s - The character sequence containing the integer value to parse.
        Returns:
        The value parsed.
        Throws:
        NumberFormatException - if the value is malformed or overflows.

      • validateString

        public static void validateString(String what,
                  String s)
        Ensures that a given string is a valid metric name or tag name/value.
        Parameters:
        what - A human readable description of what's being validated.
        s - The string to validate.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the string isn't valid.

      • resolveAll

        public static ArrayList<byte[]> resolveAll(TSDB tsdb,
                           Map<String,String> tags)
                                    throws NoSuchUniqueName
        Resolves all the tags (name=value) into the a sorted byte arrays. This function is the opposite of resolveIds(net.opentsdb.core.TSDB, java.util.ArrayList<byte[]>).
        Parameters:
        tsdb - The TSDB to use for UniqueId lookups.
        tags - The tags to resolve.
        Returns:
        an array of sorted tags (tag id, tag name).
        Throws:
        NoSuchUniqueName - if one of the elements in the map contained an unknown tag name or tag value.

      • resolveIds

        public static HashMap<String,String> resolveIds(TSDB tsdb,
                                ArrayList<byte[]> tags)
                                         throws NoSuchUniqueId
        Resolves all the tags IDs (name followed by value) into the a map. This function is the opposite of resolveAll(net.opentsdb.core.TSDB, java.util.Map<java.lang.String, java.lang.String>).
        Parameters:
        tsdb - The TSDB to use for UniqueId lookups.
        tags - The tag IDs to resolve.
        Returns:
        A map mapping tag names to tag values.
        Throws:
        NoSuchUniqueId - if one of the elements in the array contained an invalid ID.
        IllegalArgumentException - if one of the elements in the array had the wrong number of bytes.

      • resolveIdsAsync

        public static com.stumbleupon.async.Deferred<HashMap<String,String>> resolveIdsAsync(TSDB tsdb,
                                                                     List<byte[]> tags)
                                                                              throws NoSuchUniqueId
        Resolves all the tags IDs asynchronously (name followed by value) into a map. This function is the opposite of resolveAll(net.opentsdb.core.TSDB, java.util.Map<java.lang.String, java.lang.String>).
        Parameters:
        tsdb - The TSDB to use for UniqueId lookups.
        tags - The tag IDs to resolve.
        Returns:
        A map mapping tag names to tag values.
        Throws:
        NoSuchUniqueId - if one of the elements in the array contained an invalid ID.
        IllegalArgumentException - if one of the elements in the array had the wrong number of bytes.
        Since:
        2.0

      • looksLikeInteger

        public static boolean looksLikeInteger(String value)
        Returns true if the given string looks like an integer.

        This function doesn't do any checking on the string other than looking for some characters that are generally found in floating point values such as '.' or 'e'.

        Since:
        1.1
